text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ELIZABETH M. DUNCAN

Present Address 403 DIRE ROADRS NEW WESTMINSTER

Pioneer Address DENGARTH, ASSINIBOIA, N.W.T.

Year you came to Saskatchewan 1884

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ELIZABETH M DUNCAN

Present Address 403 Duke Road R.R.S. New Westminster

Pioneer Address PENGARTI4 ASSINIBOIA N.W.T.

Year you came to Saskatchewan 1884

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.*

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 8 or more.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 3

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Two or three times per year.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On such days.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We went visiting our neighbors just when the notion took us.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the morning so we could be home before dark.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? We always stayed for meals even when we were invited beforehand.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

When our neighbors came unexpectedly they were made very welcome without any words of "take pot luck" in fact I never heard the words used by pioneers.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? There was always a meal offered our visitors even if had to be made early at noon or evening as the case might be.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? It was seldom any person staying to "look after the place."

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, the women always helped quilt, sew, when their neighbors came to visit.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There would be dances in the homes but I never even heard of what dances until many years after the days of pioneering had passed.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? In the winter months we used to hold dances each one had one or two dances through the winter of course neighbors with the largest room to dance in was the ones most chosen.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

REMEMBER VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? On which days?

3. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the evening, was there a chance to stay after it became dark.

4. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? How was the invitation to have meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potlucky" used, or was some other expression common?)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bees," when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? In the summer months, are such to hold dances, and in what manner?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. If you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

After 1914 the school house was used for community dances, Christmas tree concerts, etc.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Waltz, Polka, Barn Dance, Can-can, Quadrille, Bon Ton, French Waltz, Reel, Ragtime, Rag Waltz, Step, Hop, Hoop, and all the old Scotch dances.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Yes, some of the old timers did not allow either dances or cards to be held in their homes.
2. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pictures, etc.)

3. If you have not described these in the school questionnaire, give dates.

4. What was the first community hall built?

5. How large was it?

6. Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

7. Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

8. To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

9. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8), 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

10. How were babies and small children provided for?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

12. Was there card playing for a prize?

13. What dances were popular?

14. Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

15. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

16. Yes, some of the towns did not allow card playing in their homes.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?  

I remember a woman that had "swank" in her home she lived in the small town of Lumsden she was laughed at by her neighbors and as time went on she became just plain Mrs. J.P. Miller.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?  

Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

After 1904 changes in social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?  

Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?  

Nearly all farmers belonged to it.

How many women belonged?  

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?  

Yes

When was it organized?  

In the early 30's

Approximately how many women belonged to it?  

About 95 percent

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3.

12. What attitudes did smallpox or measles do you remember in small towns, such as Brownville? Was when calling, calling cards, visitors treated differently?

13. Was the obverse known in your community? Describe what you remember about obverses, telling how common they were.

II. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not likely to be found that were popular at parties and give approximate dates when you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

after 1904 change in social life became noticeable

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.
Who provided the lantern and the slides?
What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypesg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
4. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1911, and places, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

There was a general lunch and women took lots of pies and cakes in fact all good things of every kind that could be eaten and these were table-made in a grove of trees and every one ate at the little tables.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Lots of tea and coffee

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

In the morning, followed by a dance at night
22. What winter games were played outside — fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter — card games such as "whist," "poker," "rummy," "checkers" or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. That arrangements were made for eating — was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Built in Lumsden in 1904 Hockey
31. Describe any features of this place which you remember as noteworthy.

34. Describe any different kinds of plants which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community plant, school or Sunday school plants, family plants, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in plants since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

26. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and what was done (boys, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1916, giving date of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local opera days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Built in Burnside in 1904 Hockey
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

I was too young to remember what both my parents brought with me. I remember Robinson Crusoe by Defoe, Uncle Tom's Cabin by Harriet Beecher Stowe, Pilgrim's Progress by John Bunyan, and Fenimore Cooper's books. We had the Western Witness and the Southern Messenger.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? All of them.

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

We borrowed all the books they had.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

Yes, in later years I bought dozens of books.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? (May 1944)

41. Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

42. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known teams, such as May 24th or July 1st)? (June 14th)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? All of them.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

48. Was there a school library? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school textbooks as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have? None

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library — how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? [Joni]

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   First a Bell organ then a Dominion piano

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.
   A large part

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. [yes]

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   Old Folks at Home, Old Black Joe and most of the old songs

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
   Who started it? How long did it continue?
   How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?
   What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
54. What musical instruments did you bring with you?

55. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? (Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.)

56. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your band entertainment in early years in the West? (Describe.)

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

57. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

58. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

59. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

60. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? Who started it? How long did it continue? How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? 

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in Ohio musical circles? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. In what an important or less important in your community has been connected with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests

66. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, autographs, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
Oxford
